messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 22, 2020 - April 28, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-04-29T23:04:51Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-04-22T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-04-28T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200429-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-04-29T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-05-05T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate.  There are some active regions present on the solar surface that might generate some activity.  On 2020-04-29, active region 12761 had an eruption around 05:30UT as seen on the SDO imagery.  There was a CME associated with this eruption, visible around 07:54UT from STEREO A coronagraph. This CME is currently being measured.   Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to a possible disturbance from an S-type (<500 km/s) CME that was first visible on 2020-04-27T13:54Z from STEREO A coronagraph and a possible impact from the CME mentioned above.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 15, 2020 - April 21, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-04-23T00:01:03Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-04-15T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-04-21T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200423-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2020-04-20T09:00Z-15:00Z.  This minor geomagnetic storm was associated with the arrival detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 of a S-type (<500 km/s) CME around 2020-04-20T01:20Z.  The CME was first seen on the STEREO A coronagraph around 2020-04-14T21:54Z.  The CME arrival was then followed by a coronal hole high speed stream around 2020-04-21. The solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2020-04-22.  

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-04-22T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-04-28T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are no significant active regions present on the solar surface as seen on the available imagery. 
 Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  Currently, the solar wind speed detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 has values of ~480 km/s due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above.  We may see another enhancement due to the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2020-04-27.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 01, 2020 - April 07, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-04-10T01:34:28Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-04-01T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-04-07T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200410-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the reporting period of 2020-04-03T21:00Z-24:00Z.  This very minor enhancement was associated with a minor disturbance seen in the solar wind magnetic field data observed by DSCOVR and ACE at L1. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu starting at 2020-04-01T15:05Z.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated to a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2020-03-30 (see notifications 20200401-AL-001 and 20200403-AL-001).  They remained elevated until 2020-04-03 and went back to nominal levels on 2020-04-04.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-04-08T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-04-14T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate.  There is some low flare activity from the active region 12759 and there are other small regions that have not been numbered yet. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the possible arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream on 2020-04-10.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continuing Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-04-03T17:20:11Z
## Message ID: 20200403-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2020-04-01T15:05Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by  high speed stream starting at 2020-03-30T11:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-04-01T15:05:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 25, 2020 - March 31, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-04-01T23:32:14Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-03-25T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-03-31T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200401-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.      

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods from 2020-03-30T21:00Z to 2020-03-31T09:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2020-03-30.  Solar wind speed reached values of >530 km/s on 2020-03-31.   

The >2 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was above the threshold of 10^3 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period until 2020-03-26T12:25Z.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were elevated due to a possible combination of several small coronal holes high speed stream arrivals detected by ACE at L1 on 2020-03-21 and 2020-03-23, respectively (see notification 20200325-7D-001).  They remained below the threshold of 10^3 pfu for the rest of the reporting period.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the significantly elevated electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-04-01T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-04-07T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There is only one active region as seen on the available imagery and it has low magnetic complexity.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to a possible arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2020-04-05.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s  
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score
